newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech Skoda Auto chief dies in car crash.
newsitem.headline: Czech Skoda Auto chief dies in car crash.

text.p: Ludvik Kalma, the chairman of Volkswagen AG's Czech unit Skoda Auto a.s., was killed late on Sunday when his car crashed into an oncoming truck, a company spokesman told Reuters on Monday.
Milan Smutny, confirmed that Kalma's Skoda Octavia was hit by the truck as it passed through an intersection close to the southern Czech town of Tabor. He gave no further comment.
Kalma had been at the helm of the Czech car maker since April 1991.
The Czech news agency CTK reported the cause of the accident was unknown, but said an investigation was underway. It did not say if any other people were injured in the crash.
Kalma helped oversee the recently-launched Octavia, which is built on a common VW platform designed for the 1998 Audi A3 and upgraded Golf.
The car is a continuation of the firm's break from the boxy Communist-era Skodas. The Octavia has more modern but conservative lines, somewhere between a Ford Mondeo and Audi's A-line.

Volkswagen, according to a privatisation agreement with the Czech goverment, originally took a stake in Skoda in 1992, and increasing its holdings in Skoda to 70 percent last year from 60.3 percent under the deal.
